title: Ticket #7481: condor_off -startd -peaceful continues to run new jobs
description:
condor_off -startd -peaceful continues to run new jobs, and a subsequent -graceful is ignored.

My expectation is that "condor_off -startd -peaceful" should prevent any new jobs from starting and request running jobs to checkpoint, but not kill any that ignored that request. And that a subsequent "condor_off -startd -graceful" would re-request checkpoints but then after some minutes kill jobs that ignored that request.

Note, I forgot about -force-graceful, which did set a timer and forcefully kill jobs. However, please remind me why that option is needed? In particular, why doesn't -graceful imply -force-graceful if -peaceful has already been requested?

2020-Jan-21 09:53:05 by tim:
Alternately, you could use condor_drain with a command-line option to determine what the machine does after drained. Tell it to stay in drained state after fully drained. ToddT prefers this because: 1) fast and easy, obvious when command has succeeded; 2) you can cancel condor_drain, which you cannot do with condor_off -peaceful

2020-Jan-21 09:53:40 by tim:
Stuart agrees to stop running condor_off -peaceful and switch to condor_drain
